description: Full send! This place is fire, it's very reasonably priced $3 a pupusa. Iv been here like 10 times here's what to get: pupusas. The revuelto is great, the loroco (its like a plant with some flavor) or just cheese are bomb. Start with 2 they fill u up fast. Def not a healthy restaurant but my lord is this place dank as all hell. Friendly staff oh sorry and the egg breakfast dishes are good too. The plates are dank but a little pricier. Authentic!
author: David W.

description:
I have been looking for a good spot for pupusas (a regular lunch staple back when I was living in LA), and this place definitely takes the crown! 

Not only is it close to the 24th St. BART, but it's also usually a really short wait. There are unfortunately not enough people who frequent this excellent restaurant, which is good for me because that just means there's less of a wait for me!

The pupusas themselves are delicious and unique. They're always made to order - you can even watch the ladies make them behind the counter if you want! I always get a variety of different flavors, with my favorite being any sort of cheese and pork combination. Even though I consider myself a big eater after 2 of these usually I'm full. At $3 a pupusa, you really can't beat the price or the quality.

I wish it was busier as this place definitely deserves more business. Next time you have a hankering for good, cheap eats then this is your spot!
author: Jenny D.

description: Delicious Pupusas and Salvadorian Horchata!! I totally recommend this place great service to.
author: Erika M.

description: I love me some Elsy's. They're my favorite pupusaria in San Francisco (better than Reinas) yea I said it. I had one and I was hooked. They also have this melon aqua frescas and it is sooo fresh. They're go good. Worth the price too - I'm used to paying about $2 per pupusa and they're a little bit more than that but worth it
author: Jaleesa A.

description:
I came into Elsy's yesterday for lunch, with my Salvadoran friend who was introducing me to this hole in the wall. I was super excited to have pupusas as I don't get out much to the Mission for it, so it was a treat! 

It's a quaint little place, divey, no frills, but the food looked good and the place felt promising. It took a moment for my friend and I to be noticed by the staff but we just seated ourselves (guess that's how it goes here.) 

We sat for a few solid minutes without receiving any menus, so my friend ended up having to go and grab it (ugh -_-) Then we waited a while until they came to take our order. 

The staff at Elsy's are very stoic and nonchalant. Like a robot. No enthusiasm, but b*tch face they had down. Our drinks and chips & salsa (only $.99! I liked the salsa- is spicy!) came out in a timely manner, however the pupusas took a little longer, and the side of fried plantains took forever and the side of beans and sour cream- EVEN LONGER! Also, when I was trying to get their attention for extra ice and proper to-go containers it was pretty much a fail. 

BOTTOM LINE. Food was good, but service was painfully slow. Was going to give this place 3 stars, but while writing this, remembering how unexceptional and disappointing the service was, I'm knocking off another star.
author: Victoria T.

description:
I was next door at La Taqueria and so annoyed by the wait time and how its so gentrified with everybody in the city paying for $7 per super taco! 

I stumbled upon Elsy's sign that says "pupusas" and I've been curious on trying a pupusa so I went in to order two pork and cheese pupusas and to go and they were done within about 8 minutes and they didn't forget the pickled cabbage or the spicy red thing either. 

BOIIIII.... after I took a bite of them, I was a happy non-crazy girlfriend again because I was already upset that I had to withdraw cash at La Taqueria and there was a wait for food and a wait for seating. Elsy's did not have that and I loved it!

The pupusas were crispy and not too dough-ey, while still being flavorful and not greasy. The pickled cabbage was the cherry on top.

Will be back!
author: Crystal C.

description: Absolutely the WORST customer service experience! Ps. I only went because La Taqueria had a long line and i was super hungry. I normally enjoy pupusas in sf too, this was my first and last time ever coming here. I was better off waiting for La Taqueria or going across the street to Red Cafe, that have amazing food and service. The Lady at cashier needs to have training on how to Greet, Treat and Assure their customers are satisfied, I left so upset. First off i asked for Spinach/Cheese w/Revuelta and she said they don't have spinach but they do have Zucchini, i was like okay i'll take Zucchini/Cheese and a Revuelta. ( I saw a cash only sign) but i also saw a Visa/Master Card and told her i only brought my card she said it's fine they just have a surcharge (which is fine) but she looked annoyed at that. Plus i asked for water & looks like it rubbed her the wrong way. Anyways, I sit and wait for my food about 20 min and when she gives it to me it's to go, when i've been at a table and have a dinning cup with water, but that's besides the point. So i start eating my zucchini pupusa and when i cut through the second ITS ONLY CHEESEEE???!! i'm like ???? confused at this point, i call her over and let her know it's only cheese?? she said yeah ( and has a sarcastic/unpleasant look ) you ordered cheese. And i told her No, i asked for zucchini and cheese and a revuelta total of two pupusas, but i would NEVER order just cheese??? that's like a wannabe quesadilla... so she continues to say yes you said cheese and i tell her again no, i know i mentioned to you Revuelta, so she just has this look of , is that all?? and i look at her and tell her " this is not what i ordered" ( can i even show her proof??) no, because the receipts given here don't say what you order.. then she just looks and walks away?? just walks away leaving me upset knowing i didn't order a plain cheese pupusa and FORGET WHAT THE CUSTOMER says because "I" employee is right and don't care about what customers feel and if i was wrong i don't care to fix it ? Like what could have fixed it here was even saying a "I'm sorry, maybe i didn't hear you or understand " " sorry for the mix up, here let me even get u a zucchini replacement instead but instead she walks away, leaving me upset. I won't ever come back here. What a shame and we communicated in spanish.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Table for 2
Walk-in, seat yourself. 

At first glance: It's packed, space is narrow and no large tables so do not come here with a large group and expect to share a table.  From where I sat you could observe the cooks and most of the wait staff. The tables were cleaned 
Nothing going on with the decor.

Ambiance: Loud, lots of families, and a much older crowd. Not much for divers patrons sitting inside. 

Ordered:
Imported Sangria drink
Salsa and Chips... .99 awesome deal.
Dos Pupusas Platter, revuelta (pork, cheese, beans)
Bistec Salvadoreno
 

Taste: 
Sangria - The taste was sharp,really hard to describe. But it definitely was not the sangria that we are use to ordering. 
Salsa - Spicy ! Chips could use a squirt of lime juice.
Pupusas Platter - Warm soft dough of yummy goodness! filled with pork cheese beans. Side of cabbage
Bistec - Salvadorean style steak made with onion, tomato and bell peppers, a side of rice, beans and fresh garden salad. Very large portion!

Service: Was okay, as expected.
author: Jessica L.

description: Pupusas were bomb! And the sauce is to die for. Always take some home with me for later. Yum
author: Amanda L.

description: I purchased a chicken soup for my dad who was not feeling well. Chicken soup came with a chicken leg quarter and salad. It was delicious. It helped boost my dad's appetite and energy. Staff and the owners are very friendly. Overall great customer service. I will recommend all my friends and family to come here.
author: Mila N.

description:
We were admittedly headed to a different restaurant recommended to us until we saw it was too crowded. We looked in the window at Elsy's and noticed an open table.  We're really glad we did!

Friendly staff and a good menu of options at reasonable prices.  It was an enjoyable Mission District experience to hear Spanish spoken by people over dinner along with sounds of sizzling food and music from the kitchen.  

We tried three different and delicious pupusas and a Salvadoran style steak served with salad, rice, and beans (pupusas were the favorites).  Together this was more food than expected.  Great all around experience for an affordable neighborhood meal.
author: R S.

description: First time eating a pupusa && it was really good, filled with a lot of cheese && meat. Little place in the way, I will come back again for sure
author: L C.

description: Hmmm where to start. Overall my experience was terrible. Since I arrived I was met with cold service and unwelcoming vibe. I ordered the huevos con chorizo and two cheese pupusas and I received both of them... ABOUT 40 MINUTES LATER. Plus when the waitress arrived with my food she also spilled some juices from the food on my hat which has not come off. Needless to say, I am never returning and I advise all to avoid this joint like the plague.
author: Gaven B.

description: Yum, I always order the 2 pupusas de arroz con queso y frijoles, and the side of rice and beans. And then mix my curtido and salsa roja, it's all so freaking good. The pupusas are amazing.
author: Walter P.

description: The cashier was hardheaded.  She would not allow me to get only one pupusa even though it's offered on the menu and I pointed to it.  Not sure why she held steadfast to this rule since we stopped by after the lunchtime rush and they only had 4 diners.  It was such a turn off that we just left to go somewhere else.
author: Amy J.

description: I give it 3 stars. WHY? Okay I try and be as real as I can when I leave reviews. But this place gives you HORRIBLE SERVICE if you're not Hispanic lol I keep going cause it's cheap and good food (but now I go only with my mom and aunty because they're Hispanic) but every time I go in there I had to break out my Spanish for any type of "Good Service" I remember I went there with some friends and it took over 20 minuets to order and over 45 minuets for our food and it wasn't even busy... lol BASICALLY IF YOU HAVE THE PATIENCE GO HERE OR IF YOURE LATIN LOL. HORRIBLE TO SAY BUT TRUE...lol I only go with my mom now and FORGET ORDERING OVER THE PHONE TO PICK UP. THEY NEVER ANSWER I SAY THIS BC IM A LOYAL CUSTOMER. EVEN WITH THE HORRIBLE SERVICE I STILL GO FOR THE FOOD IF THAT SAYS ANYTHING...
author: Alejandra B.

description:
The original plan was to grab some burritos from La Taqueria next door...but the line was waaaaaay too long and so we were standing outside thinking about where could we eat instead. That's when we looked inside Elsy's Restaurant, which looks like the quintessential hole-in-the-wall: sparse decoration & locals eating.

And when I mean locals, in this case it would be Salvadorians. And although I can't vouch for their ethnicity, just the fact that entire families including kids were enjoying their meals, was enough to convince me to try this out.

We sat at the counter and right away our waiter came over. Having absolutely no idea what Salvadorian cuisine/food is like, we asked him what he would recommend: he then told us that the pupusas here were the most-wanted item on the menu. Pupusas, we learned, are blown-up tortillas with filling inside. They're quintessential Salvadorian! So, we opted for these and then also ordered the Salvadorian Steak, which comes with a pepper-onion sauce and is served with rice and mashed beans. As a drink, I ordered Tamarindo.

Eventually the cheerful music would start - not unsimilar to the traditional Mexican tunes - and we knew we were in for a real treat.

All in all, I very much enjoyed our visit here. The food was tasty and I especially liked the authentic feeling here...I really wish that with the ongoing gentrification in the Mission, places like this will still survive...
author: Uli B.

description:
1/22/16

I found a hair in my pupusa! This is disgusting!

Bought an order to take home to share with family & right as I was going to take a bite I find a strand of hair inside the actual pupusa. 

The cooks clearly need to wear hairnets! 

If you really wanna eat here I would just recommend you check your food before taking a bite.
author: Jaritza M.

description:
Walking in the street, here by random to try. 
Such a huge deception, it already doesn't look good about the restaurant from outside but the food does.
Inside this is loud and small, booth (in wood) are so uncomfortable and small, I personally had a hard time to eat even if I'm thin. Staff doesn't speak English, not easy if we don't have some notions. Restroom are disgusting, it was 4 pm when I was there so kinda busy but no one checks it. 
About the food : tasteless, they probably save money on the meat. The drink are small and overpriced. 
"People love us on Yelp" on the door should not give confidence.
author: Mael D.

description: I went to eat at the pupuseria I was waiting for a chicken soup and I saw when the cook who was in the kitchen went to the back side of a trash container to take out cans and empty bottles I saw her because she was in the back Sitting and watched as she came straight into the trash and then watched as she went to make tortillas again talk to the owner about this insidious but she told me that she had seen that same but also saw that she washed her hands And he did not say anything else but in my opinion I have worked a lot in the kitchen and we have never been allowed to go to the garbage container because we are working with food the truth does not seem  at all hygienic
author: Jacqueline R.

description: Been wanting to try papusas for awhile now since I only had it once very very long time ago from a friend. Me and my friend decided to come here after deciding for a long time if we wanted to try it because we were both hesitant. Walked in and we were greeted by maybe the owner also the cook as well. We ordered two papusas at $2.60 each or $5.20 for both. The selections are limited but I stuck with beans and cheese as my friend got pork,cheese, & beans. I also ordered chips and salsa and the total was less than $7! Chips came in after two minutes after paying and right away I can tell they make their own chips(yay). Ten minutes later, in came our papusas and we were so excited to try it. It tastes like a closed up fried quesadilla, maybe a little thicker but it was so good. The beans are smashed up as the cheese was melted and gooey. YUM! If you're ever craving papusas, come here because they are known for them. Friendly staff & cheap prices as well, I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Was visiting the mother in-law in the Mission and hunger struck! It was one of those days. I had to have my pupusa fix.  

And, La Santaneca was closed. Damn Monday!!

Low and behold.... Elsy's to the rescue!!!

Atmostphere = humble, diner ambiance
Bean y Cheese Pupusa = excellent
Loroco (Flowers) y Cheese Pupusa = delish (if you've never tried it, the flavor is similar to zucchini)
Maduros y Crema = the well-aged plantains were beautifully caramelized, cooked to perfection
Horchata = very good authentic, chalky rice and cinnamon flavor, not the artificial sweetener and fake flavor kind

I can never finish two pupusas in one sitting, especially when it comes as a combo plate with the refried beans and rice.  Doggy bagged it home and had a long afternoon siesta.

Yup, if you eat hear do not plan anything afterwards.  You just can't!
author: Jen A.

description: I guess they do not like pets? Not even services dogs ?. My mother has a heart problem and our dog is a service dog and the lady that works there said no service dog unless the person is blind?! Bullshit someone should tell them their laws
author: Chris H.

description: Been here a couple times, and it's my new favorite for pupusas. It's all about the curtido (pickled cabbage) for me, and they do it right here.  Pupusas are a little less greasy than others I've had in the mission. Service is always friendly and fast.
author: Nigel W.

description:
This place was really good. I was asking my friends how do you pick which restaurant to go to in the mission when most of them sell tacos and burritos? And then realized...sell pupusas. DUH!!! 

This place was a whole in the wall and filled out much needed cravings. We knew it was good when there were no "transplants" in the waiting area. HA! It looked to be family owned and the smell was so good. 

I got the pork and cheese pupusas. They were so fresh and good. I love the little crispy sections of the crust where the cheese gets a little burnt. LOL. I tried my friend's bean and pork one and it wasn't my favorite. A little too dry. Their cabbage salsa was on point too and they aren't skimpy on the red salsa either. Definitely eat it while it's still smoking hot.

I will definitely be back and I want to try more of the options and the horchata.
author: Simone J.

description: I love pupusas, but the quality of the service is too awful to overlook for the food. Maybe they are understaffed because there are often lots of people sitting around with no food. I could probably forgive that if I didn't feel like I'm being ignored. Last time I went in, I wanted to order food to go. I stood by the register for 10 minutes and despite walking by me numerous times, my presence wasn't even acknowledged. I went to La Taqueria instead. Despite the long line there, when I came out with my food, the same crowd was sitting around here, still with empty tables!
author: Gwen H.

description:
I LOVE pupusas so it is very hard for me to give a pupuseria such a low review, but this place is awful.  

They said 10 minutes, and in reality I waited 30 minutes for 4 pupusas.  

I ordered pupusas de chicharron y queso, and they gave me revuletas.  

Their curtido is weak.  Basically just cabbage.  

Never coming back.
author: Geoff P.

description: I don't get why this place only gets 3.5 stars, it's much better than that. Good sign? We were the only non-Hispanics in the place which was packed. We had the best platanos I've ever had. Chicken tamales were great. Had a couple of other good items. Service was slow but warm and friendly and they got the order right!
author: Ottis M.

description: I always walk in and order, the food is ok, I've had better. This time I decided to call in and order for pick up.  I understand the language barrier, I was able to place my order but when asked how long until my order was ready she told me to hold on and hung up on me, I called back 5 times and each time she hung up on me because she didn't understand my question, How long will my order take?  Good way to loose a customer, so rude. Might be a good idea to have a bilingual person answer the phones.  I will never go back, go to La Santaneca down the street, much better food.
author: Belynda S.

description: The pupusas are not the best I have had in the Bay Area, but it is good enough. One lady that works there has a difficult time being friendly to those that are not fluent in Spanish hence the 2 stars.
author: Bella M.

description:
Elsy's has all kinds of interesting facts on the walls about salvadorean dishes/eats.

obviously salvadorean so went for the pupusas:

eats: pork (chiccarones) and cheese (2/4.50)
-packaged in aluminum foil, curtido and salsa in plastic baggies
hey! it cuts down the overhead and landfill waste
-pupusa huge, fillings tasty, shell a bit toasty (like it!)

leftovers:
-best most recent pupusa ever ate
-note on wall states U.S. Dollar is currency in El Salvador since 2002?
-home cooking feeling
said "gracias" to owner. he smiled and said about the same thing.
author: Victor G.

description: Service was the absolute worse. Refused to greet us and waitresses passed us at least 5 times before asking if we needed anything. It got hostile when my boyfriend needed to use the restroom (medical complications where he needs to use one often) and a women who I assume was a cook kept banging on the door for him to get out. (He was in there for less than 5 mins!) She would not listen and repeated to call me names in Spanish thinking I wouldn't understand. We walked out without bothering to pick up our to go order (dirty kitchen anyway) and went right next door to La Taqueria and got the best service! Total flip of a coin. Disgusting how they treat customers.
author: Rosie A.

description:
Came to Elsy's to try  pupusas for the first time.  We ordered:

Revuelta (Mixed) - Shredded pork fried to perfection, beans, & cheese
Chicharron y queso - Pork and cheese
Queso - Cheese
Frijol y queso - Beans & cheese

We watched them make our order fresh and took it home to eat.  All were delicious.  A little salty (in a good way), and inexpensive considering the size and quality. 

The pupusas were served with a cabbage mixture (kind of a vinegar slaw) and a red sauce.  Both were a little bland, but not offensive. I'd like to see a little more spice in the sauce. 

A yummy experience!
author: Nick G.

description:
Pupusas are very delicious and fresh!
I've been there several times. They may take a long time on your order, depending on how many clients. But the staff is nice :D
author: Maritza S.

description: The Papusas was standard. It was bland with no thrills, but edible. The service was good as you order and receive your plates.  It may take awhile if it gets busy as the Papusas are made fresh.  Double check you bill.  As I got home, I calculated my bill and realized I was overcharged. I even tipped them well, but the damage is done.
author: Chan M.

description: The pupusas were delicious! I would recommend eating there and not taking it to go. Took a little long to get the food the staff is friendly the place were pretty busy. It was worth the 15-20 minute wait. Love the chicharron pupusas with fruit salad
author: Selene L.

description:
Oh, Wow. Most amazing masa makes everything here authentically scrumptious.  I have eaten my fair share of pupusas. It's hard to make a really good pupusa.  Here, I found the ultimate pupusas, hands down.

Now that I think about it, Please do NOT try this place. When I went, it was really easy to get in, no wait, and the service was timely and pleasant. If suddenly it becomes popular (with others than the El Salvadoran grandmas and day workers I dined with), it will be a drag to have to wait to eat.

So, this place is SO good, I really prefer you not go there. Thank you.
author: Jesse Clifford A.

description:
We picked up some pupusas here.  It was a little more expensive than I am use to paying for pupusas, but I'm from LA.  We have tons of competing pupsarias there.  

Tasted great!  I recommend it!
author: N L.

description:
Ok only been here once but that's enough for me I love pupusas and this place really brings out flavor in the meat and the cabbage doesn't get any Better than that 

The environment is not so bad it gets rowdy and it's a family place only saw families in there when me and my friend went.
Didn't matter though me and my friend pratically swallowed our food and left in 10 minutes.. Not much to say about this place but the must have pupusas and I'm sure we probably will be coming back great service and friendly people haha gotta appreciate the good customer service!
author: Dana W.

description:
I seated myself, and was ignored by both servers on the floor for 10-15 minutes. Two groups that came in after I did were seated and served before me. I seriously considered leaving, but I couldn't give up so easily right in front of delicious Salvadoran food. 

Finally, I mustered the courage to go up and stand next to the cash register to get someone's attention to be served. It was embarrassing, but I was desperate and not giving up.

I still ended up ordering quite a lot of stuff. I loved how their horchata is more on the darker side than what I usually expect from Latin/Central American restaurants. The pupusas (I ordered three all different fillings) of course were pretty good too. 

The loroco --flower/fern-y edible plant native to El Salvador-- pupusa was a bit lacking. I would have loved to see more of those greens. I tear pupusas into halves and quarters by hand to eat (as any respectable Salvadoran would tell you so), it's also a good way to check if the pupusas have been filled properly. The curtidos also felt...off. They gave me a nice cupful, along with that red tomato sauce in a convenient squeeze bottle, but the pickled shreds were too dry and not sour enough.

Very nice portions for the price, plus I got a free plain pupusa, I guess as their apology for ignoring me earlier.
author: Clare Y.

description:
Walked past this place after dinner and asked my friend the fatal question "what's a pupusa?"

Dinner round 2 :p

For those of you ignorant to El Salvadorian food like me this is the definition.
"Pupusas are basically corn tortillas stuffed with any combination of pork, cheese, beans, and a few other ingredients. They're cooked for 8-12 minutes over a griddle by our skilled pupusa artesans. All pupusas are served with curtido and traditional salsa."

I remain neutral to the dish.  Interesting to try though and at only $9 for 4 pupusas it was a bargain!
author: Angela Y.

description: Papusas were delicious, large, and inexpensive (~$5 for 2 bean & cheese papusas).  Minus one star for service.  My take-out order took a long time and I stood at the register for awhile before anyone would acknowledge me.
author: Sona P.

description:
I'm absolutely coming here again.  I was craving soup last night of the Latin variety, so my two friends and I walked from 22nd and Mission up and down the street going into various taquerias in search of soup.  I was surprisingly disappointed because a lot of places didn't have soup on their menu, but what disappointed me most was the taqueria that had soups on the menu but said no soup today.  

Our last stop was Elsy's, and I must admit I had given up on soup and was about to grub on some papusas.  We walk in, and my friend asks if they have soup, and the cute, kind employee says yes.  We sit wherever we want, we get menus, and the cute waiter guy takes our drink order.  I cannot emphasize how amazing the customer service was!  

I ordered the chicken soup, my friends each ordered three papusas, all of a different variety.  We also ordered chips and salsa which cost a measly $.79 and came with refills.  The salsa was unique, not super spicy, but had a yummy taste to it.  My soup came in a big bowl with fresh, warm tortillas, and a side of rice which I dumped in the bowl.  I took the chicken out the bowl and shredded it myself and tossed it back in, and once I added the Tapatio and squeezed the lime in, I was on cloud 9.  I tasted the papusas my friends had ordered, and they were so delectable, fresh, filled with melting cheese.  One friend ordered a side of queso fresco, which our waiter informed us is house-made.  

Five stars, five freaking stars for Elsy's.
author: Sarah B.

description: Elsy's is a gateway into the city's best pupusas. Very basic menu that's easy to follow. I'll make it even more simple for you...order at least 2 pupusas, they'll include some salsa and cabbage along with it. I'll be coming back for more of their awesome pupusas.
author: Jaime W.

description:
Gender bias.

No male chickens here. Just grilled organic hens. Your choice of leg or breast with rice, salad and homemade tortillas on the side.

Appreciate the swap of refried beans for the rice. Still a guilty a pleasure, but a better tasting one.

Tortillas were the best part. Thick and chewy. Wish there had been more meat and less bone on the breast. 

More refried beans came with zucchini in a pupusa. Another delicious guilty pleasure. Paired with the main dish total came to $15 and change.

While not overwhelmed by the food appreciated the authenticity of the service and experience in the face of continued gentrification. Places like this make the Mission home.

And that's a completely biased statement.
author: Jason B.

description:
The staff here is very friendly and you can tell that they care about their product and the people that eat it.  They have reasonable prices and have great friendly service.  The pupusas here are really good, but what I enjoy the most here is the Salpicon. 

Salpicon is a dish where beef is cut up into a million tiny little pieces and has a lemony flavor, and is served with sides of rice and beans.  Most restaurants (and my mother) put the beef in a blender and let it shred the beef for what seems like hours.  This method sucks the flavor out of the beef and you end up getting dried meat--ELSY'S does not do this!  Their meat tastes great.  

If you are coming here get pupusas, of course, but also try the salpicon.  It is really, really, really good here.
author: David C.

description: Try out papusa! It's an awesome dish: corn dough with cheese and meet, grilled. Tomato sauce.
author: Mark T.

description:
We popped in here early on a Friday evening because my partner had a craving for pupusas.
He placed an order for two chicharron and cheese pupusas, then took a seat and waited.  It took about 15 minutes for his take-out order to be filled, then we went home and ate.
He liked his pupusas very much. The corn tortillas were nicely grilled and filled with pork and cheese.  The curtido was chilled and provided a nice contrast to the hot, spicy pupusas.  The salsa was delicious but too hot for him, but it was fine to me.
He got four corn tortillas but could eat only two, so we saved the rest for lunches.
We were pleasantly surprised at how good his dinner was.
author: Philip C.

description: Trying to find another  restaurant but found this place instead! The pupusas are delicious!! Two pupusas for $4.50, a pretty good deal. It is all made by three Salvadorian ladies and is all made to order. Great place, definitely a bit of a dive but the atmosphere is very authentic and the food is excellent.  Definitely worth a trip if you're craving hearty food on a budget.
author: Katie C.

description: Got a Delicious Bistec encebollado with a tamarindo juice. The food here is very tasty with real latin flavors. Although we didn't try the Pupusas, they look so good.
author: Lorena B.

description:
I am a lover of pupusas who currently lives in a county devoid of a single Salvadorean eatery.  Elsy's satisfied my need (not a want, but a NEED) for a pupusa con loroco y queso.  I could see a woman making the pupusas right there, just for me.

Aside from a sad experience with a frozen Goya product, any pupusa with loroco is a good thing. The curtido was just fine, and the sauce was a little bland. But the pupusa itself was fresh and gooey and filled with happiness.
author: Cherie C.

description: To keep it simple, it's a must try! The environment is relaxed. There is not a lot English being spoken, but it gives to the environment and a real feel of the culture around you.
author: Franchesca L.

description:
Really good food. Love the pupusas, game hen soup and their nachos. Well priced.

Also, not sure if that's Elsy behind the counter, but she was incredibly sweet and helpful.
author: Ankur V.

description:
This review is based only on their pupusas  and salvadorian quesadilla (don't hold me accountable for their Mexican menu)
I have been going to this place for years! Hands down the best pupusas in the mission... I always go here because their pupusas remind me of home (el Salvador) the cheese is melty, they are not too thick and doughy, they make a good curtido and salsa. The horchata is also quite good, they offer salvadorian and Mexican horchata. I love their salvadorian quesadilla, super yummy even more so if they heat it for you :-)
The restaurant is not fancy or anything but pretty good compared to all other pupuserias- and the bathroom is always clean. The service is really good, the server/ cashier is very nice!
I drive all the way to the mission from Marin to eat their pupusas so trust me, they are good!!! :-)
author: Andrea A.

description:
Pupusas are good, but I feel like they're the same quality as many restaurants in sf. 
Service: Bad, bad bad. We came in and just stood at the door for a couple minutes feeling awkward waiting for anyone ine the restaurant to acknowledge us, we seated ourselves since a table was being cleaned. Its so true that time is irrelevant to them. We waited about 10 minutes to even get a menu. Had to ask for chips and salsa, the waitress said they dont give them to anyone unless the customer asks for them, and whispered "cause there's an extra charge for chips & salsa."
Who cares if you charge me! Justgive me chips and salsa! Also, no napkins at the tables?  You also have to ask for them. Our order came and the waitress said it wrong so I made sure it was right. She flipped her hand like "whatever, yeah, ill tell the cook if it's wrong. I would just take it to go, if I really really had to go. But won't be going back.
author: Luis and Yona V.

description: The pupusas were out of this world!! Until my friend and I found a piece of metal inside of the pupusas.  It was a traumatizing experience to say the least.  We will overcome this hard obstacle together.  At least we got the meals for free today so we yolod it.
author: Hideki S.

description:
It looks old, plain and authentic; a woman stands in the open kitchen slapping and shaping pupusas by her huge bowl of masa.  Pupusas are $2 each with a minimum order of two.  They don't have as many varieties of pupusas as Balompie Café.  In addition to pupusas, the menu includes burritos, breakfast items, combo plates, soups, etc.

I was in the soup mood, so I ordered something from the soup menu (can't remember the name, I think it had Indian in the name), $10.75.  A big bowl of soup arrived along with a separate plate with steamed white rice, grilled hen (your choice of leg or thigh), salad, a wedge of avocado, and two plain thick tortillas (they looked like plain pupusas).  

The soup was a clear light broth filled with big chunks of carrots, zucchini, celery and potato.  I was hoping for a heartier soup with hen in it, not a rice plate with veggie soup.  The hen had a nice crisp skin but didn't seem to have seasoning other than salt.  It was simple and plain - and the meat was quite lean.  

The pupusas were greasier than Balompie's and uneven in shape and thickness.  The filling was coming out.  Balompie's pupusas look and taste better.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Fantastic pupusas but they don't give you enough curtido so you ask for more and they charge you. What? That's preposterous!

The pupusas are a good size, stuffed well and not oily at all. Nice crispiness on the outside and well cooked but still fluffy on the inside. Mmm, mmm. 

I was just pissy that they skimped on the curtido. C'mon people!
author: Margo G.

description: The Papusa were very bland and dry. The cabbage was also bland with no kick to it. I was very disappointed. The Plantain was good though. I will stick to La Santeneca any day! Plus this place didn't have Pollo Encebellado.
author: Rod W.

description: Fantastic pupusas! Had to hobble down this way because the restaurant we were supposed to go to was closed! Best decision ever! My tummy is so happy right now!
author: Shirlene M.

description:
We wented to eat someplace else but they were closed on Easter Sun 4/4/10 and B. just picked this place.

It's a Salvadorian restaurant.  It wasn't very busy when we went in.

B. got a lengua plate $8.50 - why get lengua in a Salvadorian restaurant?  He's not good at ordering.  The plate had one 3 lengua (tongue) pieces w/ rice and side of salad & side of refried beans.  2 homemade tortillas given on the side.  Lengua wasn't very tender, rice - I didn't try, beans - runny, tortillas - good.

He also picked Orchata - a little bit different from a Mexican Horchata - rice milk drink.  Sweet w/ cinnamon served w/ ice.

I got 2 pupusas - those are Salvadorian & the lady was standing by the window making them fresh.  Menu says minimum 2 pupusas.  They are $2 ea x 2.  Side of cortida (pickled cabbage) - just ok.
#45 Revueltas $2 - cheese, pork meat, & beans.  I liked it fine.
#49 Zuquini con queso $2 - zuquini & cheese.  Not as good as Revueltas, but finished both.

One unisex bathroom in the back - not very nice.

Just ok, nothing special here.
author: Ann L.

description:
Something about Elsy's just makes me feel at home. I tried the pupusa platter the other day and it was the bomb! 

Can't go wrong with bean and cheese pupusas. Amazing, delicious and inexpensive meal. Give it a try!
author: Margarita B.

description:
3.75 stars

On a whim, ended up at Elsy's. It was a Tuesday afternoon and the place was not very full. Ordered and sat down (I think I was so hungry I didn't want to wait for my pupusas to be made)

I tried thier  pupusas revultas and my friend had a chicken tamal. I typically don't like salvadorean tamales (sorry picky mexican that I am), but Elsy's makes a damn good one. Only complaint is that there were a ton of bones in this one, kind of took away from the yummy factor.

Pupusas were good size, tasty...but just "OK". I felt like the filling was kinda meh, the cheese was either too little or not the right kind (?).  I had to ask for seconds of curtido, something about these places in SF just never serve me enough of it. 

I might return to try other specials on the menu--since I know that everything is fresh and has 'homemade' quality.
author: Hilda Z.

description:
I'm fascinated by the pupusa woman at Elsy's. She stands behind the front window everyday using her magic hands to pat, massage and roll a hand full of masa into fresh, juicy pupusas. I met up with my Yelp buddies David N and Kent P for brunch this morning and the pupusa woman was there working her magic, pimp slapping my order of fat pupusa. The place is a straight hole in the wall with an open kitchen to bring about a quaint, homey dining atmosphere. There were a few hanging Salvadorian artifacts including a display of colon while the humble place is furnished by large tables to accommodate large families and their whopping bowls of soup that looked straight up hearty and delicious.

With David and Kent both had mixed combination of pupusas at $2 each, I ordered a chicharron con queso pupusa ($2) to compliment a bowl of menudo with pigs feet ($8.50). We all agreed that their pupusa were humongous with excellent fresh masa texture and cheese, but the meat was not visible or enough to let its taste stand out. The slaw was not as crunchy as expected while the red salsa was too watery and watered down. Luckily, my experience was dramatically different from my brunch companions as my soup was excellent. It was enriched with large thick cuts of tripes, chunky vegetables, and bulky pigs feet with a side of cilantro, red peppers, onions, and two thick masa tortillas. The combination of it all was flavorful and savory, just perfect for today's cool rainy weather. Additionally, I also thought the fresh warm masa tortillas were bread-like and delicious. I can literally eat them for fun all day long.

Service-wise, this is a family operation where everyone, aside from the pupusa maker, has a role in cooking and managing the tables. This resulted in slower service and things can get overwhelming in the presence of large groups. Anyone who wishes to dine in should anticipate some wait time within different stages of the dining experience. Three stars for my pupusa and four stars for the soup resulted in my 3.5 stars rating.
author: Daniel L.

description: OMG.... The Best Pupusas I've ever had! My favs: Zucchini & Cheese and Pork (chicharron) & cheese!!! A must try Yelpers when in the Mission District.
author: April M.

description:
We walked into Elsy's and the restaurant was packed. No vacant tables. But a couple were just leaving and offered us their table. Yes the table was all messy with their stuff but they had just vacated the premises so that was ok. It took a few minutes but the waitress finally cleaned it up. The restaurant looked liked it had been there for centuries but from my understanding, they had just opened up a few months ago? I suppose they were trying to capture that old El Salvador feel. Well they got it right.    

Pupusas are surprisingly pricey compared to La Santaneca but they were bigger and had more cheese in them. Both my dining guest and I ordered the 2 pupusa plate with rice and refried beans. It took a while cause they had only one waitress for the whole joint. When we got our order, I noticed the rice was white rice with vegetables, La Santaneca's rice is yellow but it was ok. The refried beans were the puréed kind which was cool. The curtido, pickled cabbage, was surprisingly good, sweet, the vinegar wasn't too strong like Santaneca's. 

My dining guest ordered a Tamarindo beverages. I only asked for water but it never came. (However, their beverages are bigger than La Santaneca.) Had to wait to get home to wash the food down with orange juice. Then it seemed like an eternity to get our check. Waitress didn't check up on us once. She looked extremely busy. 

Summary: not likely to go there again. La Santaneca is better in our opinion.
author: Cesar B.

description:
Some sounds in my world are simply awesome -
the sound of opening a new can of tennis balls
the sound of birds chirping early in the morning outside my patio
the sound of my basketball making a swoosh
the sound of a bottle of champagne popping
the sound of a chime commencing a yoga class
the sound of my niece laughing

and then you have the sound of older Latin women clapping masa to make pupusas

Point is: Seriously delicious pupusas can be found here.  I'm also a fan of La Santeneca down the block, but this place is a complete surprise.
Must try if you have never been

Lunch special  2 pupusas, a salad & iced tea instead of soda - $6. Deal.
author: Athena S.

description:
Pros: 
-The slapping sound of handmade Pupusas rang throughout the place
-Pupusa with cheese and zucchini was my favorite
-Cheap place to eat ($2/pupusa)

Cons:
-Very long wait for both dine-in & take out patrons
-Not meant to handle more than 6 people in your party.
author: Lisa R.

description:
The service was friendly and clear, albeit in Spanish.  The soups looked great, I wish I ordered some.  

The food tasted homey and filling - the stuffed pepper enchilada was good and well flavored.  They don't do custom pupusas, in particular, you cannot order pupusas stuffed with just meat.  That was disappointing.  

There was a list of rules on the wall on how to eat your pupusa.  Following the rules gives the pupusa a much different taste - neat!
author: Di Yin L.

description: You can't beat the lunch special- 2 papusas & a can of soda plus salad for under $6! Fresh ingredients, not at all greasy. Good service, clean Establishment
author: Maria T.

description:
This Pupusas are as good as it gets !! 
Good portion size and good prices I will most definitely be going back.
author: Eddie C.

description: The best Sopa de Gallina, Horchata and Pupusas in the Mission that I have tried so far. I definetly recommend this place as one of the few good Salvadorean restaurants in the city!!
author: Jorge M.

description: Friendly staff, pupusas made on the spot with handy instructions on the wall on how to eat like a local (split it in two, add salsa & curtido, roll one half, eat!). Usually pretty busy, zero hipsters and the food is cheap!
author: David M.

description: Mm best pupusas that aren't in El Salvador ,good chicken plate and good people :) .always right
author: Keith A.

description:
Tried their organic hen soup and menudo, and both were good. Salvadorean menudo was better than traditional Mexican menudo. Less hominy and other shit. Hen soup unexpectedly came with an entire chicken leg, rice and salad. That was a nice little surprise.

All in all, best papusas that we've had so far. Even after trying many of their soups and entrees, the papusas are still easily the best thing on their menu.

We are eagerly awaiting for them to reopen at the end of this month.
author: Nathan C.

description:
One of my friends is from El Salvador and was shocked that I had never tried Salvadorian food despite my Latino background. She insisted that I go with her to the Mission and try one of her favorite places.

We walked into Elsy's and were greeted with warm smiles, with the cook laughing at my friend for bringing yet anothet new person to come try the food out.

She ordered us the vegetarian pupusas. I was expecting the salsa they had to have some sort of spice to it since I am so use to spicy Mexican food, but my friend explain to me that Salvadorian food did not have much spice to it.

I was surprised that I did not find the food bland, but it was quite savory. While I enjoyed the pupusas, I could not handle the salad they gave us, which was bland. My friend pushed me to try the Jamaica (pronounces: he-my-ka) drink, which is infused with a flower. It was too sweet for my tastebuds and I was completely overwhelmed by the flavor.

Overall, the food was GREAT! Delicious pupusas for about $3- can't beat that!
author: Surge C.

description: Since I've found this spot, it's the only place I come to for my pupusas! They are the best ever! And this should tell you a lot. . I drive from San Mateo CA to SF just to eat here! That's how bomb this place is. Every person I have brought here becomes an addict of their food! Best place to go in the city!
author: M M.

description:
People come here for the pupusas, despite the menu also featuring burritos and soup. I've come to Elsy's twice so far, and these are my thoughts:

1) Pupusas are made fresh and they're cheap ($2 each, 2 pupusas minimum per order). They're brimming with fillings such as cheese, vegetables, meat, etc. There are several different kinds to choose from, and each of them are served with a side of cold vegetables and salsa.

2) Service is a little awkward in terms of ... how do you order food? The first time I came here with Lolia S., we had a server take our order at our table. The second time I came here, we ordered at the counter. I guess either way works, but it seems to be expected that customers order at the counter regardless.

3) Tamarino (sp?) soda was overly sweet yet still delicious. They also have sangria soda. Too bad there wasn't any alcohol (I kid).

4) The bathroom could be better in terms of cleanliness. I'm strange, but I tend to judge establishments' restrooms.

Overall, I liked Elsy's and wouldn't mind to come back again. Would I say that their pupusas are fantastic, out-of-this-world? Unfortunately, I can't speak much on that aspect since I've only tried pupusas at one other restaurant before Elsy's. I'll get back to you on that one.
author: Helene K.

description:
Came here after realizing the SF Street Food Fest was absolute insanity, and that our hungry tummies could not withstand 40 minute lines.

If I could give you one word of advice, it would be DON'T BOTHER WITH ANYTHING BUT THE PUPUSAS (w/ rice and beans on the side, if you choose).  My friends got the quesadilla and the combination platter, and were both "meh" about their dishes.  However, we unanimously agreed that the pupusas were delish.  I got the veggie one and the chicarron y queso - large, satisfying, and cheap.  Would come back for 'em again, although I hear there are better ones in the neighborhood...
author: Allison B.

description: This is one of my favourite pupuserias in San Fran. I always eat here after playing tennis - sometimes I order a proper plate/meal but quite often I just have 2 pupusas, have them on the table, and it cost only $5. It is quite authentic - just like the ones I ate in El Salvador. It is definitely not a place to linger (they don't serve alcohol and they accept cash only) but it is a simple and basic restaurant with great food and friendly waiting staff.
author: Mikki G.

description:
My El Salvadorian friend introduced me to her beloved culture and favorite restaurant. Since then, I have introduced my other friends to this friendly restaurant with great tasting food. 
They are never shy to show you how their Salvadorian flower/vegetable Loroco* looks like, which tastes good in pupusas.
Their drinks, El Salvadorian Cola, etc. are good too. Both Vegetable and meat options.




Loroco:
http://www.google.com/imgres?imgurl=http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Loroco.JPG&imgrefurl=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Loroco.JPG&usg=__6g3KJz11UlgPId3b1DPi-8lhuLg=&h=1944&w=2896&sz=216&hl=en&start=18&zoom=1&tbnid=RQB5bITb17duAM:&tbnh=136&tbnw=175&prev=/images%3Fq%3Dloroco%26um%3D1%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DN%26biw%3D1258%26bih%3D564%26tbs%3Disch:10,556&um=1&itbs=1&iact=rc&dur=740&ei=JW_MTJ7wH4uosAPu3v32Dw&oei=Hm_MTPeRMYSesQOR4bCNDg&esq=2&page=2&ndsp=22&ved=1t:429,r:20,s:18&tx=78&ty=54&biw=1258&bih=564
author: Tigre T.

description: Went here after 8 on a thursday with a friend who lives on the area. Not much in terms of ambience, but makes up for it with authenticity and flavor. I had the zucchini and cheese pupusas and a tamarind juice. That was way too much food for way to little $...I ate it all anyway because it was delicious. If I lived nearby, I'd definitely go back. The curtido had a unique and pleasant kick to it and the service came with big smiles. Mucho gusto.
author: Abby D.

description:
terrible food. terrible ambiance. terrible service. 

I got the grilled organic chicken plate for 10.50.  way overcooked, dry, mostly skin and bone, almost no meat.  The plate was filled with white rice and salad (iceberg lettuce with bits of carrot).   DO NOT GET THIS DISH!!  I was soo hungry after eating it.  

Their ensaladas were the same deal- mostly iceberg lettuce. 

I noticed that some of the other customers who looked like locals got much better treatment, including more food and complimentary chips and salsa.  

my friend ordered a horchata and it never came.  

ambiance is garish yellow lighting, cramped booths.
author: T Y.

description: The people here were super nice and the food was delicious.  Just wish this place was closer to my way home.
author: Ray A.

description: We stopped in here after being terribly disappointed by La Taqueria. I was still hungry after that silly lengua burrito. So we got pupusas! The boy and I ordered one each, and then when they were brought to the table, we jumped right in. Three minutes later, the server brings us another pupusa, telling us that instead of giving us two different ones (we ordered two different ones) they gave us the same one twice. So we got a free pupusa! For $2 a pupusa, they're cheap, and we got one free. They were tasty, and well worth it. That single pupusa sent me over the edge though, because after that, i felt like a whale with two legs. I was too full to eat anything else, so we thundered back to the bus stop. An evening well spent.
author: Angeline P.

description: Excellent chicken soup, especially the broth.  Not fancy.
author: James C.

description: Friendly staff.  Delicious pupusas for $2 each (minimum 2).  I wish they had more salsa options, but otherwise it's a great place for cheap yummy pupusas.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I was sure I had written a review for Elsy's on Yelp long ago . . . . hmmmm.

I love Elsy's.  I get pupusas revueltas, to go, every single time I am in the Mission.  I get enough to have a meal and then to take home. They might taste better on the reheat.

Like others have noted, this place is a dingy hole in the wall but the woman who makes pupusas in the window, working off a gigant pile of dough, shaping them, slapping them on the grill, filling them. . .. seeing them made, feeling the good nature of the women who work there, also of the guys working at the cash registers much of the time. . . everything about this place if wonderful.

I never try anything else, but I always want to. It is often busy, often families.

I love the pupusas. Next time, I'm going to try the salpicon, a soup another yelper raves about. Sounds very tasty. It's just that when I am in the Mission, I eat burritos, which is why the pupasas tend to come home with me. I'm already full when I get to Elsy's.

Don't be intimidated if you are a gringo, don't let the cosy Latino vibe keep you out. People are people, and when people are gatehred together over good food, they are nicer than usual.

These folks are very very very nice.
author: Shaniqua A.

description: This restaurant makes the best pupusas in the city.  I have been to some famous ones in the city but Elsy's pupusas always come out on top.  I love them for the fact that the pupusas are kind of crispy on top and bottom ( kind of reminds me of a good pot sticker's crispiness) while my favorite filling of revuelta has the best combination of pork, beans and melted cheese.  I also love their atole de elote....I went again this evening and the owner's son was there helping out and provide an excellent and thoughtfull service..Thanks Jimmy.
author: m c.

description: A place run by friendly aunties... this Salvadorean restaurant is the real deal.  The food is homey and the tamales and pupusas were out of site.  The price is right and will now be on the regular rotation.
author: Laurence H.

description: It's a pupusa restaraunt.  If you've tried one, you've tried them all.  But that doesn't make the food any less good for the price!
author: Jason B.

description: I have tried 4 Salvadorian restaurants of pupusas in San Francisco in the past and this restaurant impresses me. Fast service, good price and delicious food. Cannot complain and will eat as much of theirs I can.
author: C G.

description: Every time I've come here, always great... Papusas. I haven't had anything else, but those are tasty, affordable and come with slaw. TOO GOOD!
author: Abbey J.

description:
We couldn't figure out how the service worked, so we just grabbed a menu and seated ourselves.  Apparently that wasn't a problem, and we ordered at the cashier.  At the front display there were some amazing looking dishes, specifically the FRIED CHICKEN.  I asked the guy at the register and he told me it wasn't on the menu yet, but you must do yourself a favor and try it.  It was great!  Not greasy or dry at all.  Who'd have thought you could find such good fried chicken at this place?  

Next time I come here, I might just skip the pupusas all together, as good as they were.  I feel bad for giving this secret away, lest I find myself waiting in some ridiculous line in the future, but the dude who worked there was so nice, I just want to see the business get recognition.
author: Ahma G.

description: The naughty slap-slap of masa enhanced the ambiance of this quaint little shop in which one can find rather wonderful Salvadorean cuisine.  In my three-or-so visits, I ordered the combo with two pork/beans/veggie pupusas, rice and beans.  The 'pusas were very good, coupled with a helping of lettuce and further enhanced by the bottled red sauce.  As there is a bevvy -- a veritable slew -- of Central and South American restaurants, it's hard to say that Elsy's is the best, but it's certainly worthwhile when you get the urge for authentic pupusas.
author: Victor R.

description: I love the service and the food come try their pupusas or their breakfast. Every time a in the mission area I go their. The honer is wanterful with customers.
author: manuel h.

description: I've tried a few Salvadorean restaurants in the city and this one is the best.  Hands down.  It's a hole-in-the-wall establishment with a big personality.  The staff is super friendly and what's really cool is that you can watch them make the traditional and delicious pupusas.  They put a healthy amount of cheese in the pupusas, which I appreciate.  The price is right as well.  Their quesadillas are also excellent.  I go here all the time and the staff knows me and my friends by name.
author: Mike B.

description: The pupusas are really are lacking, but it's close to work and often you just crave something cheesy and greasy.  My last order was a caldo de res, which I grew up with at home. Not only did they forget to make my order when I called it in, but the two women were incredibly rude when I reminded them of the order and asked how long it would be so I could just come back. As this is the second time I've recieved attitude from them, I will not be stepping back in. There are much better places in San Francisco for pupusas.
author: C. G.
